Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ F w/ PMHx of HTN, HLD, PVD, COPD, history 
of rectal cancer, and anemia who presented from cardiology 
clinic with symptoms of dizziness in setting of new onset atrial 
fibrillation found to have over-repletion of thyroid hormone, 
hospital course complicated by acute pulmonary edema.  

# Acute Pulmonary Edema: Early on the morning of ___, the 
patient woke up acutely short of breath and hypertensive to 
systolics of 200. A chest x-ray showed worsened pulmonary edema 
in RLL. She was treated with 40mg IV Lasix and a nitroglycerin 
drip. She required BiPAP and was transferred to the CCU where 
she was treated with 3 additional doses of 40mg IV lasix over 
the course of 2 days. She only required BiPAP for 6 hours, and 
was then weaned to nasal cannula oxygen supplementation. 
Nitroglycerin drip was weaned off and home dose amlodipine was 
restarted. Review of the TTE showed 3+ MR ___ etiology thought 
to be possible flail mitral valve leaflet) as the presumed 
cauase for the patient's acute pulmonary edema. The patient 
continued to received IV furosemide on the floor with 
improvement in oxygen requirement with the patient on RA on the 
day of discharge. The patient was transitioned to PO torsemide 
___. The patient was started on losartan for after load 
reduction as well as metoprolol. Weight on day of discharge: 
47.7kg.

# Atrial fibrillation: CHADS-2 score of 2; patient has never had 
a stroke or TIA in the past. Patient was rate controlled on 
metoprolol XL 100mg and converted to sinus rhythm on the morning 
of ___. Thyroid function testing revealed over repletion which 
may have been the etiology for new afib. Levothyroxine dose was 
decreased to 112mcg daily (from 135mcg). TFTs should be repeated 
in 6 weeks for discharge from ___ on this new dose. 
Anticoagulation was discussed with the patient's outpatient 
providers (Cardiology and Primary care physician); given the 
patient's history of falls, the decision was made to use full 
strength aspirin for anticoagulation.  Patient's metoprolol was 
decreased to 50mg metoprolol XL in light of development of acute 
pulmonary edema. 

# Pyuria: Early during admission, patient had UA suggestive of 
UTI with 49 WBC and few bacteria. Urine culture with less than 
10,000 organisms. Patient received 3 days of ciprofloxacin.  

# MRSA cystitis: Patient had Foley catheter placed during 
admission while being digressed. The patient's UA was suggestive 
of UTI but patient without white count when debris noted in the 
Foley catheter. Foley was discontinued. Urine culture showed 
MRSA, and patient complained of symptoms of dysuria. 
Sensitivities showed that MRSA was sensitive to Bactrim DS BID; 
patient was started on Bactrim ___. Blood cultures 
pending; repeat urine culture at time of discharge pending. Plan 
for 7 day course of Bactrim DS BID with day one being ___.

# PVD: ASA 325mg PO daily. The patient was started on 
pravastatin, which she should continue as an outpatient.
 
# HTN: The patient's home amlodipine was discontinued during 
this admission, while metoprolol was started and adjusted. With 
the development of acute pulmonary edema (see discussion above), 
metoprolol was decreased and ___ (losartan) was started for 
afterload reduction. ___ as opposed to ACEi was started given 
the patient's underlying cough.
 
# Hypothyroidism: TSH 0.091, FT4 2.1, consistent with 
over-repletion. Decreased levothyroxine from 135mcg daily to 
112mcg daily. Recheck TFTs in 6 weeks from discharge from acute 
hosptialization and adjust dose appropriately.
 
# Anemia: CBC stable through admission. Continued home iron 
supplementation. Patient due for B12 injection per daughter 
which she received during this admission. 

# COPD: Continued home tiotropium, Symbicort and albuterol.

# Thoracic spine area skin breakdown: Patient with Mepilex 
placed. Trending exam. Encourage ambulation. 

# CODE STATUS: FULL CODE. There had been discussion with patient 
regarding her code status. She had expressed desire to be 
DNR/DNI though patient's daughter had much difficulty accepting 
this code status. On-going discussions regarding code status 
will need to be carried out upon discharge from hospital.

Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure caring for you during your hosptalization at 
___. 

You were hospitalized because you were found to have an 
irregular rhythm of the heart known as atrial fibrillation. We 
have started you on medications to help control your heart rate. 
We discussed starting anticoagulation with your primary care 
doctor and cardiologist and the decision was made for you to 
take full dose aspirin daily. The good news is that during your 
hospitalization your heart rate converted to normal rhythm. You 
will continue to take aspirin to reduce your stroke risk. 

During this admission, you were found to have a urinary tract 
infection. You were started on antibiotics to treat the 
infection. You will complete a 7 day course of antibiotics.  

Please see your discharge paperwork regarding medication 
changes. 

Weight on discharge: 47.7kg.

We wish you the best going forward.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old pleasant lady who presents with history of 
worsening cough and shortness of breath on exersion as well as 
urinary frequency. The patient was previous prescribed 
levofloxacin and Z-pack prior to admission. However one day 
before admission her symptoms became worse prompting her to see 
her PCP who referred her to the ED. 

# UTI: Her admission labs were notable for a UA suggesting a UTI 
and an elevated Cr to 1.8. She was started on PO Cipro for a 
presumed UTI. First urine culture returned negative but pt still 
reported urinary sx so a second urine culture was sent and is 
pending at time of discharge. She completed a 5-day course of 
Cipro while in-house and her Cr improved with IV fluids. 
Discharge Cr was 1.1.   

# COPD exacerbation: pt's wheezing thought most likely to be 
COPD exacerbation. Her CXR excluded pneumonia, and her blood 
culture excluded sepsis. Since the patient recently finished a 
course of azithromycin prior to admission she was only started 
on a prednisone taper. She was discharged on a prolonged taper 
as discussed with her outpatient pulmonologist Dr. ___. 

# constipation: pt was put on bowel regimen including 
senna/Colace, lactulose, psyllium when she reported she had not 
had ostomy output for 5 days. She typically has ostomy output 
every 3 days. She will continue on senna/Colace in the 
outpatient setting. 

# urinary retention: pt was found to have persistently have high 
post-void residuals and required straight cathing. This was 
thought to be a chronic issue based on her history of UTIs and 
pyuria. She should be bladder scanned in rehab and will follow 
up with urology in the outpatient setting to discuss further 
workup. 

CHRONIC ISSUES: 

# anemia: hemoglobin trended down mildly but remained close to 
pt's baseline. Anemia is believed to be a combination of iron 
deficiency anemia and anemia of chronic disease. She received a 
unit of pRBCs for a  Hgb of 7.3, but should follow up with her 
primary care doctor about reinitiating EPO. 

# diastolic CHF: the most recent echo in ___ showed EF >55% 
and LVH with moderate to severe (3+) mitral regurgitation. The 
pt did not have s/s of CHF exacerbation in house. She was 
restarted on her torsemide at a reduced dose of 10 mg twice 
weekly. 

# anxiety: pt was discontinued from lorazepam and did not 
require treatment for anxiety

# HLD: continued home pravastatin 

# HTN: continued home metoprolol 

# hypothyroidism: continued home SYnthroid. TSH here was 3.2. 

# ostomy care: wound consult was placed for concern for sores 
around the ostomy site. The pt reports that in the past she has 
received chromalin spray that was helpful for addressing the 
sores. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUE:
=========================
- steroid taper: prednisone 40 mg for a total of 5 days then 
transition to prednisone 20 mg for another 5 days. Pt should 
continue on 30mg/day for 3 days, 20mg/day for 3 days, then 
10mg/day for 3 days, then 5mg/day for 3 days and follow up with 
Dr. ___. 
- Torsemide dose on discharge: 10 mg. Pt should take torsemide 
twice weekly as needed. 
- urine culture: pt has urine culture from ___ pending at time 
of discharge. Please follow this up. 
- urinary retention: pt found to have persistently elevated 
post-void residuals and required straight cathing. She seems to 
have h/o chronic urinary retention. She should follow up with 
urology for question of cystoscopy. She should get bladder scans 
TID and be straight cathed for PVR >500 at rehab. 
- EPO injections: pt found to have anemia of chronic disease and 
started on iron, B12 and folate supplements. Per discussion with 
pt, she should follow up with PCP to discuss whether to continue 
EPO injections for her anemia (she hasn't received any in about 
___ years). She did receive 1 U pRBCs while inpatient. 
- medication changes: consider discontinuing donepezil as pt 
does not appear to have dementia as she has relatively high 
functional status (able to use phone, engage appropriately in 
conversation etc). Pt's lorazepam was d/c'ed as she did not 
require it in house.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking part in your care while you were in the 
hospital. You were admitted because you were feeling short of 
breath. You were found to have a low sodium level, but this 
rapidly improved. You were given IV medication to remove fluid 
from around the lungs. You were also given antibiotics for a 
mild pneumonia. During the hospitalization, your heart rates 
increased, requiring adjustment of your medications as listed 
below. Your metoprolol dose was increased, and a drug, digoxin, 
was started. You also were noted to have abdominal pain and 
distension, and a nasogastric tube was placed to decompress your 
stomach, and improved your discomfort. At that time, a 
medication, diltiazem was stopped, as it was thought to be 
contributing to your stomach discomfort.

You likely developed a new mild pneumonia, and were treated 
first with and IV antibiotic, and one to take by mouth at the 
rehab. Your breathing was good without the need for additional 
oxygen at the time of your discharge from the hospital. Your 
abdominal discomfort improved as well.

WHAT YOU SHOULD DO AFTER LEAVING THE HOSPITAL:
1. Do not drink more than 1.5 liters of fluid a day
2. Drink only thickened liquids

Again, it has been a pleasure taking part in your care, and we 
wish you the best.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ year old M with PMH of CAD s/p 4V CABG 
and asthma and recent admission for colitis who presented with 4 
weeks of epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting.

Active Issues: 

# Abdominal Pain
Patient has past admission to ___ in ___ for similar symptoms, 
and workup was unrevealing. Given his history of colitis, 
gastritis and PUD were suspected. Infectious etiologies such as 
gastroenteritis were deemed less likely as he had been 
symptomatic for 4 weeks and had no risk factors such as travel, 
camping, or new foods. His lipase and LFTs were normal, so 
pancreatitis, hepatitis, or biliary pathology were thought to be 
unlikely. In addition, his abdominal CT was unrevealing. 
Finally, 2 serial troponins were <.01, and there was isolated T 
wave inversion in V2, so cardiac etiology not likely. He had no 
electrolyte abnormalities or weight loss, so he had been able to 
maintain adequate nutritional intake as an outpatient. He 
reported no known history of peptic ulcers, and H. pylori IgG 
was negative. He received Maalox, diphenhydramine, and lidocaine 
as well as Tylenol PRN pain, which helped alleviate his 
symptoms. He was continued on omperazole 40mg BID and placed on 
a full liquid diet, which he was able to advance slowly, with 
LUQ pain after eating but no vomiting.

# Chronic right upper extremity pain
This pain was thought to be neurogenic as patient laid on that 
arm for hours during his ___ suicide attempt. He had been 
asking his PCP to take him off of narcotics and agreed to 
transition to gabapentin. His hydrocodone-acetaminophen was 
discontinued and he was started on gabapentin 100mg TID, to be 
uptitrated as an outpatient.  

Chronic Issues:

# Coronary Artery Disease
s/p 4v CABG in ___. His EKG was unconcerning and there was no 
rise is serial troponin levels x 2. He continued on ASA 81mg 
daily and metoprolol 100mg BID. He had said upon admission that 
he was worried about taking ASA because he thought it might harm 
his stomach, but was reassured that he should stay on this 
medication.  

# Asthma
He had wheezing in the ED, but resolved after nebs--his wheezing 
was present once he arrived on the floor, for which he received 
albuterol nebs.  

# Depression/Anxiety
History of suicide attempt in ___. No SI. He was continued on 
sertraline, trazodone, and clonazepam BID PRN. He reported being 
in a depressed mood.  

Transitional Issues:

# Follow up on H Pylori serology (lab result pending at 
discharge). 
# Consider food allergy testing, although he did not report 
symptoms with one specific food.
# Consider GI referral as an outpatient, as he has had similar 
symptoms in the past, including an admission in ___, 
without clear cause. 
# Patient wanted to stop Vicodin. He was started instead on 
low-dose gabapentin for right arm pain. Please ___ 
response as an outpatient, consider uptitration. 
# Unclear why patient not on aspirin with history of coronary 
artery disease. Consider starting if indicated.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.

You were admitted for abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. You 
received medications to help with these symptoms. Meanwhile, 
your blood tests and vital signs (like blood pressure) showed 
that you have been receiving adequate amounts of fluids and 
nutrition through the foods and liquids you drink. You had a CT 
scan which showed no cause for your symptoms. In addition, we 
were reassured that you were able to eat lunch without any 
problems. Therefore, it is safe for you to return home and you 
can complete other tests or procedures as an outpatient.  

It is likely that your pain is from inflammation in the stomach, 
called gastritis. This can be treated with medications you are 
on (omeprazole). Your symptoms could also be from ulcers in the 
stomach. We tested you for an bacteria called H. pylori which 
can cause ulcers, but the blood tests will not be back until the 
end of the week. We and your primary doctor can ___ on 
this. This can be treated (if you have it) with a short course 
of antibiotics. 

We recommend continuing on the Maalox and liquid lidocaine if 
needed to control your symptoms. Please follow up with your 
primary care doctor after discharge. 

We wish you a safe and healthy return home.

Sincerely,
Your ___ Team

Brief Hospital Course:
=========
Summary
=========
___ year old female with history of ___ disease, 
bilateral blindness, hypertension, history of bronchitis and 
reactive airway disease brought to the ED by her son with 
several weeks of recurrent episodes of shortness of breath, 
anxiety, and gasping for air. Patient was evaluated with video 
swallow study which showed esophageal dysmotility and esophageal 
retention of barium. Follow-up EGD was done which showed 
presbyesophagus. Patient was monitored with baseline diet of 
ground solids with thin liquids with medications whole with 
pureed solids. She tolerated the diet well and was discharged 
home

========================================
Acute medical/surgical issues addressed
========================================
# Esophageal dysmotility and esophageal retention of barium on
video swallow:
Patient presented with periordic episodes of shortness of breath 
and anxiety. Suspected that symptoms likely caused by esophageal 
reflux causing her to aspirate which exacerbates her reactive 
airway disease. Certainly ___ puts patient at risk for 
swallowing issues at baseline. Outpatient CT scan did not show 
any obvious esophageal obstruction. No current concern for 
infection given no leukocytosis, evidence on CXR of PNA, and pt 
has no fevers, productive cough. Breathing remained stable on 
room air and O2 sats >90%. Both GERD and reactive airway disease 
treatment were optimized at home and this continued here. Video 
swallow ___ revealed significant esophageal retention of 
barium concerning for severe esophageal dysmotility. GI 
consulted and recommended EGD ___ to evaluate for esophageal 
ring or other structural issue that could be causing retention. 
EGD revealed presbyesophagus and atrophic gastritis. Patient was 
advised to adhere to astrict aspiration precautions at home 
including eating more frequent, smaller meals, taking small 
bites and sips, sitting upright for all meals and medication 
administration and remain sitting upright for 1 hour after 
meals. Please eat only if awake, alert, and attentive.

# Reactive Airway Disease
Patient presented with episodes of SOB and anxiety that may 
represent asthma exacerbations from suspected aspirations. 
Breathing remained stable on room air and O2 sats >90%. 
Optimized reactive airway disease treatment is optimized at home 
with fluticasone IH BID, ipratropium bromide neb q6hs, 
levalbuterol neb q6hours, Perforomist IH BID, and prednisone 
10mg PO daily. While admitted patient was treated with duonebs 
q6hrs, advair BID, and prednisone 10mg daily. At discharge, 
patient was restarted on her home medications.

# Uncomplicated bacterial UTI: Patient asymptomatic but with 
floridly positive UA and urine culture growing E. coli. Patient 
was not oriented this AM but also received Ativan in the ED last 
night. Completed Bactrim DS BID (D1: ___. 

# Hypertension: not taking metoprolol as outpatient. Will need 
to verify medication list with son. ___ pressure well 
controlled overnight and SBP 150s now. Not on Metoprolol as was 
stopped at ___ due to hypotension.

# HLD: continued atorvastatin 20 daily

# GERD: continued pantoprazole 40 mg BID. Patient was discharged 
on pantoprazole 40mg PO BID and Maalox 10mL q6hrs PRN

# ___ disease: continued home Carbidopa-Levodopa 1.5 tab 
QID and 1mg at 7pm. Also continued Carbidopa 25mg QAM per son's 
home med list.

- None

Dear ___,

___ was a pleasure taking care of you at ___

Why was I in the hospital?
  - You were having episodes of shortness of breath at home and 
were brought in to be evaluated for potential causes of these 
episodes

What was done while I was in the hospital?
  - Your gastroesophageal reflux disease medications were 
reviewed and were felt to be optimized already
  - Your reactive airway disease/asthma medications were 
reviewed and we felt you were on an optimum regimen at home 
already.
  - You had a video swallow study which showed you had trouble 
swallowing foods. We did a follow-up EGD done which showed that 
you have a condition called presbyesophagus, a common condition 
seen in elderly individuals that predisposes you to having 
trouble swallowing and gastroesophageal reflux. 

What should I do when I go home?
  - It is very important that you take your medications as 
prescribed. We will provide you with a list of medications at 
discharge that you should continue to take
  - To prevent choking and aspiration of food, which is likely 
the cause of your episodes of shortness of breath and discomfort 
at home, we recommend:
       - Please eat more frequent, smaller meals and take small 
bites and sips. 
       - Please remember to sit upright for all meals and 
medication administration and remain sitting upright for 1 hour 
after
meals. 
       - Also, please eat only if awake, alert, and attentive
  - Please go to your scheduled appointment with your primary 
doctor.

Best wishes,

Brief Hospital Course:
Brief summary: 

This is a ___ with ___ disease, esophageal dysmotility, 
reactive airway disease presenting from home via EMS with 
inability to ambulate. In the ED she was hypotensive, 
transiently mildly hypoxic, and clearly weak and 
encephalopathic. She was found to have a UTI and also thought to 
be hypovolemic. She improved very impressively with fluid 
resuscitation and antibiotic therapy, to near-baseline (though 
very poor functional status at this baseline). Her antibiotics 
were transitioned to a narrowed spectrum oral regimen prior to 
discharge.

Detailed summary:

# Urinary tract infection: Patient presenting with inability to 
ambulate, found to have positive urinalysis on admission. 
Patient denied symptoms, and was afebrile and without 
leukocytosis, but given her encephalopathy and difficulty 
ambulating, treatment was initiated with ceftriaxone. She 
improved with therapy. Urine culture with >100K E coli, 
pansusceptible. Narrowed to amoxicillin at discharge.
- Complete course of amoxicillin 500mg PO TID x5 more days

# Acute toxic metabolic encephalopathy: Patient sleepy but 
arousable on initial interview, with subsequent course notable 
for waxing/waning alertness. She improved with treatment of UTI 
and dehydration/hypovolemia.

# Inability to ambulate: Patient presenting with inability to 
ambulate, likely due to hypovolemia and UTI. Patient was noted 
to have right nasolabial flattening on exam, son is not sure if 
this was new; neurological exam otherwise seems to be at 
baseline and strength intact in upper and lower extremities and 
head CT was performed for this reason and was negative - likely 
gravitational based on serial exams. She was continued on her 
usual ___ disease medications. Her physical functioning 
improved to near-baseline (which is poor) after treatment of 
UTI/dehydration. She was seen by ___ who recommended discharge 
back to home with 24 hour care.

# Hypotension
# Hypovolemia/dehydration: Patient noted on arrival to be 
hypotensive to the systolic ___, not clearly symptomatic. 
Patient appeared dry on exam, and per report from son has not 
had much to eat or drink day of admission. BPs improved with 
IVF. Of note, patient also on prednisone 10 mg per day at home, 
completed steroid taper from last admission.

# Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: Patient found to be 
hypoxic, requiring 1L oxygen via NC in the ED. Patient was able 
to be weaned to room air upon arrival. CXR clear without 
evidence of pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or aspiration. On exam, 
patient has no wheezing to suggest acute exacerbation of her 
reactive airway disease. ___ have been aspiration event.  
Followed by Dr. ___. Home medications were continued.

# Thrush: Mild. Resolved with some nystatin. 
- Rinse mouth after inhaled steroids

# Esophageal dysmotility: Continued aspiration precautions with 
pureed solids and thickened liquids. She was seen by SLP who 
felt she was doing fairly well and could likely tolerate thin 
liquids (no straws).

# Anemia: Chronic, stable
# ___ disease: Continued carbidopa/levodopa

# Hyperlipidemia: Continued atorvastatin
# Anxiety: Continued alprazolam as needed

melatonin

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF SUMMARY: 

___ with advanced ___ disease, dementia, esophageal 
motility, reactive airway disease presenting with tachypnea in 
the setting of severe constipation. It was thought that she was 
tachypneic due to (1) alteration of respiratory mechanics in the 
setting of abdominal distension from constipation along with (2) 
some aspiration occurring in the setting of her chronic 
oropharyngeal and esophageal dysphagia worsened by the 
aforementioned tachypnea and missing her ___ 
medications. Tachypnea slowly resolved as her constipation 
resolved and she was kept NPO. She was evaluated by SLP during 
this resolution phase and was cleared for her usual diet. She 
appeared to return to her usual baseline and so was discharged 
to home with her usual services and her sons' excellent 
attentive care.

DETAILED SUMMARY:

# Tachypnea
# Mild intermittent hypoxia
# Acute hypoxic respiratory failure
# Esophageal dysmotility: Likely aspiration in setting of 
advanced reactive airways disease and underlying restrictive 
lung mechanics due to advanced kyphosis. This was all likely 
worsened/precipitated by progressive constipation, for which she 
is unable to compensate due to her kyphosis -- leads to 
tachypnea and then tachypnea leads to aspiration which then 
precipitates a viscious cycle of more tachypnea and aspiration. 
Missing her medications also likely contributing. SLP evaluated 
her ___ and felt she was unsafe for any PO, but she appeared to 
do better ___ so diet was advanced and she tolerated this well. 
She appeared to return to her baseline by today ___ and so was 
discharged home.
- Note: A G tube can be considered for her, if in the future she 
really cannot meet her nutritional goals and can't take meds, 
but when we involved her in the discussion she said she did not 
want one. She improved so this was not explored further, but it 
may present a potential barrier to pursuing tube placement in 
the future. 

# Constipation: Severe on presentation but now moving her 
bowels. We adjusted her bowel medications to maintain 1BM per 
day. Counselled son on the following regimen:
- Standing senna now BID, Miralax now daily
- PRN Bisacodyl given HS if no BM that day

# Acute toxic metabolic encephalopathy
# Dementia: Baseline cognitive status per ___ is "pretty high 
functioning," but apparently always thinks that it is ___ 
(with air conditioning always on at home), and is not oriented 
to events. Agitation on admission likely driven by recent 
constipation followed by repeated visits to the ED overnight. At 
home pt is maintained on low dose alprazolam which typically 
provides benefit for her anxiety and agitation. She improved by 
the AM after admission and appeared to be at her baseline for 
the remainder of her hospital stay.

# Advanced ___ disease: Slowly progressive per its usual 
course. Now quite advanced. Most of her above issues are the 
result of this condition. Her home medications were continued 
according to her precise home schedule and she did well. 
Neurology was not consulted this admission given her 
improvement. 

# Anemia: Chronic, stable
# Glaucoma: Continued home eye gtts
# Hypothyroidism: Continued levothyroxine
# Hyperlipidemia: Continued atorvastatin
# Anxiety: Continued alprazolam as needed
# Insomnia: Continued low dose home trazodone; substitute 
ramelteon for melatonin

>30 minutes spent coordinating discharge home

Brief Hospital Course:
# Hypoxia requiring supplemental oxygen: 
The etiology of the patient's hypoxia at home is unclear.  Her 
oxygen saturations improved quickly when she reached ___ 
ED and she was on room air when she arrived at ___.  Chest XR 
did now show a pneumonia.  I suspect she was having trouble 
clearing her throat due to lethargy (side-effect from prior 
Xanax use) and had a transient airway obstruction or mucus plug 
as the source of her hypoxia.  While she was in the hospital she 
was continued on her home duonebs, flovent and prednisone.  Her 
son ___ plans to only give her half of a Xanax for anxiety in 
the future.

# Toxic Metabolic Encephalopathy: 
Her altered mental status at the time of admission was likely 
from a combination of medication side-effect (Xanax) as well as 
urinary tract infection.  UA was positive and urine culture grew 
> 100,000 CFU pan sensitive Klebsiella.  She completed a course 
of antibiotics while hospitalized.  Sedating medications were 
used sparingly and son ___ try melatonin for sleep rather 
than a benzodiazepine.  Trazodone was held.  

# Troponinemia:
- Initial troponin at ___ was 0.02.  She was 
transferred to ___ for further evaluation.  Her troponins 
trended 0.02 --> 0.02 --> <0.01.  Her EKG was unchanged from her 
baseline and she did not show any signs of ACS.

# Constipation: Continue senna, Miralax, bisacodyl

CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS:
# Anemia: Chronic, stable
# Glaucoma: Continued home eye gtts
# Hypothyroidism: Continued levothyroxine
# Hyperlipidemia: Continued atorvastatin
# Anxiety: Continued alprazolam sparingly as needed
# Insomnia: Substitute melatonin for trazodone at discharge
# GERD: Nexium

with her medications and honey thick diet in the hospital.  She 
showed no signs of aspiration.  When I initially discussed a 
feeding tube with ___, she said she did not want one.  I 
advised ___ to discuss this topic further with his PCP and 
___.

oxygen levels.  You were likely altered (confused, not acting 
yourself) since you had a urinary tract infection and you had 
taken a sedating medication, Xanax, the night before.  You were 
given an antibiotic to treat your pneumonia. 

You also had low oxygen levels at home.  Since you were confused 
and sleepy, you likely had trouble clearing your mucus 
secretions.  This brief mucus blockage was the likely cause of 
your low oxygen level at home.  You did not show any signs of 
pneumonia and your oxygen levels quickly returned to normal.

At home, please ensure you give yourself adequate time to eat 
your meals.  Please decrease use of sedating medications like 
Xanax or take half a pill of Xanax.  You will follow-up with 
your primary care doctor and ___ as below.

CXR ___
Left basilar atelectasis.  No definite acute cardiopulmonary

G-TUBE PLACEMENT ___
A 65 cm, 5 ___ glide catheter was negotiated through the 
Nares down to the stomach using a 0.035 glidewire.  Position in 
the stomach was confirmed with injection of air.  The tube was 
then secured and used for insufflation.  A scout image of the 
abdomen was obtained. The stomach was insufflated through the 
indwelling nasogastric tube. Under fluoroscopic guidance, 2 T 
fastener buttons were sequentially deployed elevating the 
stomach to the anterior abdominal wall. Intra-gastric position 
was confirmed with aspiration of air and injection of contrast. 
A 19 gauge needle was introduced under fluoroscopic guidance and 
position confirmed using an injection of dilute contrast. A 
Amplatz wire was introduced into the  stomach. A small skin 
incision was made along the needle and the needle was removed. 
After sequential dilation using 12, 14 in 16 ___ dilators, a 
18 ___  peel-away sheath was placed.  A 14 ___ MIC 
gastrostomy catheter was advanced over the wire into position. 
The catheter was secured by instilling dilute contrast into the 
balloon.  Contrast injection confirmed intragastric  position.  
The catheter was then flushed, capped and secured. Sterile 
dressings were applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well 
and there were no immediate 
complications. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with ___ disease, esophageal dysmotility, dementia 
who presented with hip pain versus abdominal pain, developed 
acute hypoxia while in the ED from aspiration. Admitted to the 
hospital for hypoxia.

#GOALS OF CARE:
#CHRONIC ASPIRATION
#UNINTENTIONAL WEIGHT LOSS
   The patient has oropharyngeal dysphagia due to her advanced 
___ disease and esophageal dysphagia due to her 
esophageal dysmotility. She had been taking a honey-thick diet 
at home (mostly Boost), but had been losing weight despite the 
heroic efforts of her son to encourage oral feedings, and also 
had a clinically overt aspiration event in the ED despite 
texture modification of her diet. She was seen by speech and 
swallow, who felt that even if we thicken food enough to help 
with the oropharyngeal phase of swallow, there is little we can 
do about the esophageal issue; she was recommended for strict 
NPO. 
    Given that the dysphagia is related to issues other than her 
dementia (which is not end-stage), we felt she would be a 
candidate for a feeding tube, if within the goals of care. It 
was difficult to directly understand the patient's own goals - 
there is prior documentation that the patient would refuse a 
feeding tube, and she was able to say in AM on ___ (in front 
of myself, attending MD, RN, and son) that she would not want a 
feeding tube. Since then, she said "I'm thinking about it" when 
asked about wanting a feeding tube. It was very difficult to 
interpret patient's wishes in this setting, and as such, we had 
to rely on the patient's son and HCP ___, who is her 
___ caregiver at home. We discussed with him that feeding tubes 
do not eliminate the risk of aspiration, but that it would 
probably be safer than oral feedings and would at least help to 
deliver nutrition more reliably and successfully. After some 
vacillation, he ultimately decided he was strongly in favor of a 
feeding tube.
    As such, interventional radiology was consulted and a PEG 
was successfully placed on ___. Tube feeds initiated on 
___ - pt tolerated well prior to discharge. She will receive 
cycled tube feeds 16 hours per day. She is also continued on her 
home BID PPI (to reduce the acidity of gastric contents should 
she micro-aspirate) and on BID chlorhexidine mouthwash.

#ACUTE HYPOXEMIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE:
#REACTIVE AIRWAY DISEASE:
#CHRONIC ASPIRATION RISK:
    Hypoxia resolved over time - ultimately it was attributed to 
aspiration pneumonitis. She is followed by Dr ___ 
pulmonology - she does not have a formal pulmonary diagnosis, as 
she is unable to cooperate for PFTs, but seems to have some mild 
pulmonary fibrosis and some kind of reactive airway disease. No 
symptoms this admission suggestive of exacerbation of reactive 
airway disease. She was continued on all of her home 
inhalers/nebulizers. 

#RIGHT SIDE PAIN:
   Pt had originally presented with pain in R side while 
ambulating - though per prior ___ records, pt is largely 
wheelchair bound and requires a lift at home for transfers, so 
unclear how much she is ambulating. She has no pain on arrival 
to the floor and no pain is elicited on exam. Had CT abd without 
any findings to explain possible RLQ pain. Has had intermittent 
constipation; ensured robust bowel regimen. Clinically felt to 
be consistent with muscle spasms in the setting of PD - treated 
with ibuprofen and acetaminophen.

#HYPERNATREMIA:
   Na 149 on admission, suspect it is due to limited free water 
intake (in the setting of needing nectar-thickened liquids). 
Resolved once started on tube feeds with free water flushes.

#PARKINSONS DISEASE:
   Has progressive ___ disease with associated 
esophageal dysmotility. Continued home carbidopa-levodopa. 
Continued home Hyoscyamine 0.125 mg SL TID:PRN esophageal spasm

#DEMENTIA:
Probably moderate in severity, but hard to assess given her 
difficulty communicating in the setting her advanced PD. Mental 
status at baseline, per son.

#HLD:
Continued home atorvastatin 20mg daily.

#HYPOTHYROIDISM:
Continued home Levothyroxine 25 mcg PO/NG DAILY.

Discharge Instructions:
WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?
- Your oxygen level was low and you were requiring extra oxygen.

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL?
- You had multiple episodes of aspiration while you were here; 
ultimately, it was decided that you would have a feeding tube 
placed. You had a G-tube placed and started to receive nutrition 
that way.
- You were seen by our nutritionists and speech/language 
pathologists - it was determined that, due to your risk of 
aspiration, it was not safe for you to eat or drink anything by 
mouth. You should get all of your nutrition and medicines 
through your feeding tube. 
- You were given fluid through an IV.
- Your oxygen level improved and was stable without extra 
oxygen.
- We gave you Tylenol and ibuprofen for the pain in your right 
side.

WHAT WILL HAPPEN WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?
- Continue to take all of your medicines as prescribed.
- Continue your nutrition through your feeding tube. We 
recommend that, if you truly want to minimize your risk of 
aspiration, you do not eat or drink anything by mouth. 
- That said... many people sometimes decide to do unsafe things 
that make them happy. If you feel it is important for quality of 
life to accept the risk of taking a few sips of honey-thick 
liquid once in a while, that is not totally unreasonable. People 
want to stay healthy, but they want to be happy too! 
- Please keep all of your appointments, as scheduled.

Brief Hospital Course:
Presented with reported productive cough, dyspnea, and lethargy. 
Disconcertingly, but consistently, her son, ___ would 
often say that she had a symptom, but when the patient was asked 
how she was feeling or asked specifically about that symptom, 
she would often say she was not feeling that way.

She did have a productive cough, however she did not demonstrate 
dyspnea or lethargy during her hospital course. Her CXR was not 
consistent with PNA. She had no other findings to suggest a 
bacterial infection. It was thought this represented a possible 
exacerbation of her chronic "reactive airway disease" which, 
itself, does not seem to have a clear underlying etiology, 
though perhaps may be due to chronic aspiration. She was treated 
with her usual home medications and she did well. No additional 
steroids were given and no antibiotics were given.

Leading up to the time of discharge, the patient's son made 
numerous requests of additional testing in an apparent attempt 
to delay and/or prevent discharge. He made all of these requests 
under the auspices of "advocating for my mother," but many of 
the requests were made repeatedly, and aggressively towards the 
nursing staff, despite clear counseling by the patient's 
physicians that the tests were not necessary and would not be 
performed/repeated. His requests also did not align with the 
patient's clinical condition. On the day prior to discharge and 
the day of discharge, the patient herself noted that she felt 
quite good, was not having shortness of breath, and overall felt 
better than prior to admission. She was not noted to have any 
periods of significant dyspnea that did not respond to her usual 
home nebulizer treatments, and she was not noted to be lethargic 
during her time in the hospital.

We counseled her son that ongoing long-term prednisone use may 
not be advisable in her case.  Specifically, prednisone 
increases her risk of skin injuries (she has some already), 
slowed wound healing, osteoporosis with more fragility fractures 
(she has several already), anxiety (which has been increasingly 
problematic per family), and stomach ulcers (particularly when 
combined with Advil she takes for pain).  We advised that they 
discuss this further with Dr. ___ primary pulmonologist.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with ___ disease, esophageal dysmotility w/ chronic 
aspirations s/p PEG for feeding, reactive airway disease on 
chronic glucocorticoids, presenting with increased PEG-tube 
residuals, found to have suspected pneumonia and rib fractures 
on CT chest. Patient received treatment for pneumonia and had 
persistent
episodes of hypoxemia due to aspiration from esophageal 
dysmotility, extreme kyphosis and atelectasis, dyskinesias from 
___ disease and underlying lung disease from COPD and
bronchiectasis. The patient was planned for discharge with 
appropriate ___ services and home O2 services, but patient son 
appealed the discharge. The case was reviewed by medicare who 
agreed with the medical team. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
#Community acquired pneumonia
Patient has chronic cough with multiple recent admissions for 
increased cough and lethargy (per son's report, but some 
discrepancy w/ clinician observation, per prior notes). Has been 
afebrile, but has a mild lekocytosis, soft BPs, and a lingular 
consolidation on CT. Therefore, treated for CAP. That being 
said, CT changes and low-grade leukocytosis may simply represent 
pneumonitis from chronic aspiration +/- atelectasis. Treated 
with IV ceftriaxone/azithromycin for a total 5 day course 
(___). Persistent O2 requirement discussed below. 

#COPD
#Bronchiectasis 
#Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure 
Patient has been on 10 mg prednisone for some time now. Son 
called her pulmonologist due to perceived increase in WOB and 
respiratory distress and he recommended increasing prednisone to 
40 mg daily (she received 2 doses of 40 mg). On exam, patient 
was mildly tachypneic but without wheezing. Did not start 
prednisone burst, as pt has had well-documented 
prednisone-related side effects, and her respiratory status 
appears stable. She was continued on her home fluticasone, 
ipratropium, levalbuterol, and fomoterol breathing treatments, 
and prednisone 10mg qd. She was given guaifenasin q6h prn. Her 
fluctuations in respiratory function and persistent O2 
requirement despite treatment for CAP and COPD is likely due to 
chronic aspiration from esophageal dysmotility, extreme kyphosis 
and atelectasis, dyskinesias from ___ disease and 
underlying lung disease from COPD and bronchiectasis. The 
patient was discharged with home oxygen. She will have follow up 
with her pulmonologist to determine taper for prednisone. 

#Acute, subacute, and chronic rib fractures
Likely related to osteoporosis (w/ progressive demineralization 
from chronic prednisone use) and chronic cough. Evaluated by 
trauma, who do not recommend any surgical intervention. 

#Esophageal dysmotility
#Tube feed residuals 
Patient had one episode of 300 cc TF residual without any sign 
of clinical obstruction. Informed son that residuals do not need 
be checked regularly. Tube feeds were transitioned to the AM 
hours for 17 hours/day given family concern for aspirations from 
tube feeds. 

CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
___ Disease 
Continued home carbidopa-levodopa

DISCHARGE APPEAL
================
  Repeated discussions with ___ (Son-HCP) were held 
regarding the poor prognosis for ___.  She is prone to 
aspirations, recurrent hypoxia with repeated mucous plugging.  
Given her Parksinson's, esophageal dysmotility, kyphosis and 
deconditioning, little can be done to prevent these aspirations 
from recurring.  She already has a PEG tube in place.  Despite 
efforts to impart the fact that providing ongoing care may 
actually be counterproductive, he did not appear willing to 
listen and insisted that everything should be done.  
   He appealed the discharge to Medicare - and the decision was 
made in agreement with our assessment.  She was discharged home 
with added oxygen, suctioning equipment and followup.  

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================

[] Pulmonology: will work on tapering prednisone.
[] Neurology: continue to optimize sinemet. After receiving 
sinemet, patient is having significant dyskinesias exacerbating 
oxygen desaturations. 
[] Patient has a suction machine to help clear her secretions. 
The patient will need to have a renewed script to resupply the 
machine versus obtain a new machine. 
[] Patient was discharged with home oxygen. Continue to reassess 
need for oxygen. 
[] Continue to discuss with family that checking tube feed 
residuals are not necessary and have not been proven to show any 
benefit. 
[] Continue to reinforce the patient's progressive decline from 
underlying chronic medical diseases.

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY:
========
Ms. ___ is ___ female with past medical history of 
___ disease, advanced dementia, esophageal dysmotility 
w/ chronic aspirations s/p PEG for feeding, reactive airway 
disease on chronic glucocorticoids who presented with increased 
work of breathing and increased cough with sputum/secretions, 
found to have acute hypoxic/hypercarbic respiratory failure, 
MRSA and pseudomonas pneumonia, frequent bradycardia, and 
hypotension. 

ACUTE ISSUES 
=============== 
# Acute hypoxemic hypercarbic respiratory failure 
Initially presenting with hypoxia. Her respiratory failure 
worsened and was started on HFNC and eventually was intubated on 
___ after goals of care discussions with the family. She was 
given aggressive pulmonary toilet. Attempts to wean the 
ventilator were not successful, so she ultimately underwent 
tracheostomy placement and bronchoscopy on ___. Patient 
continued to have intermittent low minute ventilation so 
required switching from pressure support to volume control. She 
will need ongoing ventilator weaning after discharge. 

# Sepsis secondary to HAP
# MRSA pneumonia
# Pseudomonas PNA
CXR demonstrated findings concerning for multifocal pneumonia. 
Her sputum grew MRSA and Pseudomonas. For her MRSA pneumonia, 
she was given 10 days of vancomycin. For her Pseudomonas 
infection, she was initially treated with cefepime, but 
ultimately transitioned to IV ciprofloxacin for an additional 7 
days after her Pseudomonas developed intermediate sensitivities 
to cefepime. Last day of ciprofloxacin is ___. 

# Hypotension
Requiring pressors after being intubated. Likely ___ sedatives 
and sepsis. Given norepi for goal MAP >65. She did 
intermittently have brief hypotensive episodes throughout 
hospitalization that were fluid responsive. There may have been 
a component of difficulty measuring BPs given frequent 
movements. 

# Reactive airway disease/COPD
# Chronic aspiration
Patient has been on long-standing prednisone. Concern for 
chronic aspiration in the setting of esophageal dysmotility with 
kyphosis and dyskinesias from ___. Given high dose 
prednisone (50 mg) for 5 days followed by taper in addition to 
aggressive nebulizer regimen. She will be maintained on her home 
prednisone dose of 10 mg PO daily afterwards. 

# Recurrent episodes of bradycardia 
Before intubation, patient would intermittently have bradycardic 
episodes including a 10-second pause on telemetry in the setting 
of hypoxia and discomfort. Electrophysiology was consulted who 
did not feel that this regard prior to pacemaker placement. 
These episodes did not recur after intubation. Likely related to 
vagal episodes. 

# Coag negative staph in blood cultures 
Grown in one set of cultures, thought to be ___ contamination. 

# Diarrhea
C. diff negative. Likely ___ tube feeds. 

# Skin excoriations in groin
Foley placed for skin breakdown on external genitalia ___ 
urinary incontinence. 

# Hypernatremia
Likely ___ poor PO intake. Resolved with increased free water 
flushes. 

# Anemia
# Thrombocytopenia
Likely secondary to sepsis and antibiotics. Improved with 
treatment of infections. 

CHRONIC PROBLEMS:
=================
# Subacute and chronic rib fractures
Found on prior admission and thought to be due to chronic cough 
and osteoporosis. Continued Tylenol, ibuprofen and lidocaine 
patches. 

# ___ Disease
# Advanced dementia
Continued home carbidopa-levodopa and carbidopa. 

# Esophageal dysmotility
Continued tube feeds through PEG

# HLD
Continued home atorvastatin daily 

# GERD
Continued home lansoprazole 30 mg PO BID 

# Hypothyroidism
Continued home levothyroxine 25 mcg daily 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
[] Continue IV ciprofloxacin to end on ___
[] Please attempt to wean ventilator support 
[] Continue goals of care discussions if unable to be weaned 
from ventilator 
[] Please remove foley and attempt voiding trial
[] Pseudomonas developed resistance to cefepime, ceftazadime, 
and piperacillin-tazobactam. Please avoid use of these 
antibiotics in the future if concern for pneumonia
[] Prednisone taper
___: 20 mg x2 days
___: 10 mg PO daily indefinitely

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,  

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!  

Why was I admitted to the hospital?  
=================================
- You were admitted because you were having difficulty breathing 
and were found to have a pneumonia.

What happened while I was in the hospital?  
====================================
- You had testing done to figure out what kind of pneumonia you 
had.  This showed you had 2 infections call MRSA and 
Pseudomonas.
 You were given IV antibiotics to treat these infections.
 You were given higher dose prednisone to help with 
inflammation in your lungs. 
 We placed you on a breathing machine called a ventilator to 
help you breath. Because you could not breathe without this 
machine, a tracheostomy (breathing tube in the neck) was placed, 
which will help you to breathe with the support of the 
ventilator, but be more comfortable. 

What should I do after leaving the hospital?  
============================================
- Please take your medications as listed in discharge summary 
and follow up at the listed appointments. 

Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish 
you all the best!  

Sincerely,

Your ___ Healthcare Team

for MRSA and pseudomonas PNA, which resulted in trach/peg, now 
with vent dependence, who now presents from her rehab (___) 
with persistent fevers and leukocytosis despite broad spectrum 
ABX for PNA, found to have bilateral UE DVT. Fevers likely 
non-infectious, so antibiotics discontinued. Patient stable and 
discharged back to ___. 

ACUTE ISSUES 
=============== 
# Fevers
Patient presents from ___ with persistent fevers and 
mild leukocytosis despite broad spectrum coverage for her 
resistant PNAs. ID was consulted and felt that her culture data 
likely reflects colonization, given her non-inflammatory sputum 
studies, stable vent settings, and stable secretions. The most 
likely etiology of her fevers is non infectious such as drug 
fever or ___ DVT. Notably, she was found to
have RUE DVT of brachial, basilic, and cephalic veins of the 
RUE. She was also found to have LUE DVT of axillary veins (with 
PICC still in place). It is possible this could be contributing 
to her fevers. Less likely new or persistent bacterial 
infection, though viral infection could be considered. Flu neg. 

# Bilateral UE Catheter Associated DVT:
Patient presented with RUE edema, found to have RUE thrombi of 
the brachial (non-occlusive), cephalic (occlusive), and basilic 
(non-occlusive) veins. This occurred in the setting of RUE PICC 
placed in the R basilic vein last admission (subsequently 
removed). She was also found to have partially occlusive LUE 
thrombi within the axillary (deep) and proximal basilic veins, 
with PICC still in place due to necessity of frequent lab draws. 
After extensive conversation with the patient's son (HCP) re: 
risks and benefits of anticoagulation, it was ultimately decided 
to anticoagulate with warfarin, with lovneox bridge. She will 
need repeat ultrasounds to assess for clot resolution on 
anticoagulation, minimum planned duration 3 months. Will also 
need to monitor for e/o active bleeding.

# L UE Erythema
The patient was found to have L upper arm erythema in the 
setting of L UE DVT, with some excoriations of the skin. Given 
improvement with topical emollients and without antibiotics, 
this was thought to be excoriation in the setting of her chronic 
steroid use, and less likely an overlying cellulitis. This 
should continue to be monitored at ___.

# Chronic Hypoxic respiratory failure: 
The patient is trached and vent dependent in the setting of 
advanced dementia. Her Trach cuff pressures were within normal 
limits(28). She was continued on her outpatient ventilator 
settings of CMV overnight and PSV during day. Trach sputum 
cultures grew pseudomonas, but given low PMNs and scant sputum 
production with stable vent settings, suspect colonization as 
opposed to active infection.

# Normocytic Anemia
The patient has a recent baseline Hgb of 7.5-8.5, and has 
required 2u PRBC while at
___. Did have guaiac + stools there, though no evidence of 
overt bleeding. Could represent a slow GIB vs marrow suppression 
in the setting of recent infections. s/p 1UPRBC with robust 
response supporting that acute bleed is less likely. Iron 
studies suggest anemia of chronic inflammation.

CHRONIC ISSUES 
=============== 
# Esophageal dysmotility: s/p PEG: The patient was continued on 
nutrition's final tube feed recs from her last admission

# ___: Continued home carbidopa/levodopa regimen

# HLD: Continued home statin

# Chronic pain: Continued APAP. Home NSAIDs were held in the 
setting of anemia. 

# Reactive airway disease, copd: Continued home prednisone 10mg 
daily and home inhalers

Dear Ms. ___,

WHY WAS I ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?
===================================
- You were admitted to the hospital because you were found to 
have fevers at your rehab. 

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL?
==========================================
- There was a concern that you had pneumonia and you were 
continued on antibiotics. However your symptoms appeared to be 
unlikely from an infection and your antibiotics were stopped. 
- You had an ultrasound of your arm which showed blood clots. It 
is possible that these blood clots were causing your fevers. We 
discussed the risks and benefits of starting a blood thinner 
with your family, and we ultimately chose to start a blood 
thinner.
- You had low blood counts and needed a blood transfusion. Your 
blood counts improved.   

WHAT SHOULD I DO AFTER I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?
============================================  
- Please continue to take all your medications and follow up 
with your doctors at your ___ appointments.  
- Your blood counts will need to be monitored closely in the 
setting of your new blood thinner. You will also need a repeat 
ultrasound of your arms in the future to look for interval 
change in the clots.

We wish you all the best!

Sincerely,  
Your ___ Care Team

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with advanced ___, 
chronic respiratory failure s/p trach, chronic aspiration with 
PEG, dementia, hypertension, hyperlipidemia who is presenting 
with distal fibula (?tibial as well) fracture and found to have 
concerns for UTI in the ED. She was admitted to the ICU given 
chronic respiratory failure and brief hypotension in the ED 
which responded to IVF.

#Comminuted distal fibula fracture
Presenting with distal fibula fracture after having trauma on
stationary bike. She was initially placed in a right lower 
extremity splint, which was subsequently casted by the 
orthopedics service. She received her home acetaminophen dose 
and oxycodone as needed for pain control. She has follow-up 
scheduled with orthopedics. 

#Hypotension, improved
Patient was briefly hypotensive in the ED with SBPs in the ___, 
Improved with 1L NS. Lactate within normal limits. Etiology 
likely either hypovolemia vs. sepsis. Given hyponatremia, 
possibly related to hypovolemia, especially given rapid 
improvement after small amount of IVF. Some concerns for UTI as 
noted below. 

#UTI
Patient found to have pyuria on UA in setting of leukocytosis. 
No other clear source of infection. She was given a 7 day course 
of ceftriaxone as treatment for urinary tract infection which 
was then transitioned to Keflex. 

#Chronic respiratory failure 
Respiratory status appears at baseline, patient has a 
tracheostomy. CXR without evidence of consolidation. Home 
settings on trach were continued with trach mask during the day 
and ventilator at night, and her home medications were 
continued. 

___: Her home carbidopa/levodopa regimen was continued. 
She had some episodes of agitation overnight and her outpatient 
neurologist Dr. ___ was consulted, who recommended an 
additional 1.5 tabs of Sinamet as needed at 3 am for agitation. 
This was noted to improve her agitation overnight. 

#Bradycardia: While in the ICU, the patient had intermittent 
episodes of sinus bradycardia overnight in the setting of being 
off the ventilator and while episodes of agitation. EKG showed 
no evidence of bundle branch block or heart block. This was 
thought to be secondary to the vasovagal episodes given timing 
with episodes of agitation as well as being off the ventilator. 
She did not have any hypotension during these episodes and 
continued to be monitored throughout her stay.  Her son, ___, 
expressed interest in a cardiology evaluation for which we 
provided him the contact information to schedule an outpatient 
appointment as her bradycardia resolved with improvement in 
agitation and pain control.

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY
=======
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with chronic respiratory 
failure s/p tracheostomy ___ (nocturnally ventilated), chronic 
aspiration s/p PEG, dementia, advanced ___, HTN, 
hyperlipidemia, recent admission for a right fibula fracture, 
and other issues who presented on ___ with apparent 
lethargy (reported by her son, as the patient is variably 
interactive) in the setting of a reported right lower lobe 
pneumonia apparently noted on outpatient imaging on the day 
prior to presentation. On repeat imaging on presentation to 
___, there were no definite signs of pneumonia and there were 
no clinical indications of acute systemic inflammation or 
infection. She remained on her home ventilator settings at night 
and trach mask during the day. Although very broad spectrum 
antibiotics were provided on presentation in the ED, given the 
absence of infection on chest imaging and the lack of clinical 
symptoms of an acute infection, all antibiotics were stopped 
upon ICU admission, and she was monitored off of antibiotics for 
24 hours without any signs of clinical instability. She was 
subsequently discharged home without antibiotics.

ACUTE ISSUES 
============
# Concern for right upper lobe pneumonia (without radiographic 
or clinical evidence of right upper lobe pneumonia) 
# Chronic respiratory failure 
Ms. ___ has a tracheostomy tube in place in the setting of 
chronic respiratory failure, and requires ventilator support at 
night. During the day, she uses a humidifier with 3L of 
supplemental oxygen. Per history provided by her son (who is her 
primary caregiver at home), Ms. ___ has had increased 
secretions over the last week and an out-patient chest x-ray on 
___ was concerning for potential right upper lobe pneumonia. 
However, on presentation to ___, there was no compelling 
radiographic or clinical evidence of pneumonia. Blood cultures 
and a MRSA screen were negative. She specifically had minimal 
secretions on tracheal suctioning, no leukocytosis on her 
complete blood counts, no fever, no hypotension, no tachycardia, 
and no radiographic evidence of pneumonia (although her lung 
apices were not well visualized on chest x-ray to 
kyphoscoliosis). Ms. ___ was continued on her home 
ipratropium and levalbuterol nebuliizer treatemetns, and 
fomoterol(home med). Her ventilator settings should remain at RR 
___, PEEP 5, TV 300 (reduced from 400cc at home, given her 
height and predicted tidal volume), and FiO2 30%

# History of UTIs
In the ED, the patient did not urinate but on the floor she has 
been incontinent of urine. She has a history of UTIs, and during 
a recent prior hospitalizations, on ___ she grew Klebsiella 
and was appropriately treated. She had another UTI while at home 
prior to this hospitalization which was treated empirically with 
cephalexin and then switched to Bactrim. Urinalysis here ___ 
was without evidence of acute cystitis, and while there was 
initial concern for urinary retention she began to void 
spontaneously prior to discharge, and did not have any more 
issues with retention while inpatient.

# ___ disease 
# Dementia
During her last admission, Ms. ___ had some episodes of 
agitation overnight and her outpatient neurologist Dr. ___ 
___ was consulted. At that time, he recommended an additional 
1.5 tabs of Sinamet as needed at 3AM for agitation. During that 
prior hospitalization, this medication change was noted to 
improve her agitation overnight. Her son says that she 
communicates with him, is normally oriented to person and place, 
and can speak with Passy-Muir valve. We continued Sinamet at her 
home doses this admission.

CHRONIC ISSUES 
==============
#B/l UE catheter associated DVT
She had bilateral upper extremity DVTs diagnosed in ___, 
with repeat US in ___ showing no evidence of DVT. Now that she 
has been treated for more than six months, she remains on 
enoxaparin prophylaxis, which we continued during this 
hospitalization (and on discharge). 

#Hypothyroidism: We continued her home levothyroxine. 

#Esophageal dysmotility: s/p PEG: We continued the Nutrition 
service's final tube feed recommendations from her last 
admission. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
[] Follow up on respiratory secretions and respiratory status 
off of antibiotics
[] Continue to monitor for signs of urinary retention, consider 
outpatient urodynamic studies if persistently retaining.
[] Ventilator settings at discharge: RR 13, TV 300, PEEP 5, FiO2 
30%

stools have been large. Given that she has had multiple c diff 
infections, she may be resistant to vancomycin. Stool cultures 
were sent. She was started on high dose PO vancomycin and IV 
flagyl. She was given IV fluids as below for GI losses. Her 
stool output decreased, her hypotension resolves, and she 
overall clinically was stable.

# Hypotension
Patient has blood pressures as low as ___ systolic in ED. BP was 
very responsive to fluid with no need for pressors. This was 
likely due to hypovolemia in the setting of fluid loss from 
diarrhea. Possibly, a compenent of SIRS response with C diff 
infection and UTI. No evidence of end organ damage based on 
initial labs. Blood pressures on discharge back to baseline.

# UTI
Patient with urine culture growing >100K GNR bacteria. The team 
was unable to assess symptoms given her mental status. 
Therefore, given concern for sepsis, she was treated with IV 
ceftriaxone.

# Chronic respiratory failure 
Patient has a tracheostomy and requires ventilator support at 
night. Patient has a history of frequent aspirations, with CXR 
appearing similar to baseline. She was continued on home 
ventilator settings. she was continued on home ipratropium, 
levalbuterol, and Perforomist.

You were admitted for occasional wheezing and cough. There was 
concern for pneumonia but your chest X-ray did not show 
pneumonia and your symptoms quickly improved with nebulizers. 
Antibiotics were stopped and you tolerated this just fine. 
Overall, your presentation is most consistent with a post 
infectious bronchitis or asthma like syndrome.

You were evaluated by speech and language pathology who felt you 
would benefit from a ground diet with thin liquids to minimize 
your risks of accidentally inhaling some of your food when you 
eat (which can predispose to pneumonia and coughing fits).

You were deconditioned and had difficulty moving around and 
physical therapy recommended going to a rehab facility. You did 
not qualify for acute level rehab and so you and your family 
elected to go home with maximal services in order to work on 
getting stronger at home.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is an ___ year old woman with a history of 
___ disease, bilateral blindness, HTN, presenting after 
a fall and head strike without LOC at home, admitted with 
respiratory distress and hypoxia in the ED with rapid 
resolution. 

# Mechanical Fall:
Patient discharged on the same day as re presentation to the ED. 
On previous admission, patient noted by ___ to be at high fall 
risk and recommended acute rehab however son declined as pt not 
accepted to first choice rehab. Patient admitted after fall from 
chair, most likely mechanical in etiology, as he patient was 
startled and slipped to the ground and in the setting of her 
weakness and ___ was unable to stop he fall. There was 
no loss of consciousness to suggest syncope as the etiology.  
Overall picture not consistent with seizure activity, as there 
was no post ictal period, also no elevation in lactate noted on 
labs, and the patient ambulated after the event with the use of 
a walker. Imaging including CT C spine, CT Head, CXR, Pelvis XR, 
bilateral knee XR and L ankle XR without fracture or acute 
pathology. There were no focal neuro signs on exam. ___ was 
consulted who recommended disposition to rehab. She was 
discharged to ___.

# Respiratory distress/Aspiration
While in the ED the patient developed respiratory 
distress/labored respirations requiring NC. The etiology was 
concerning for aspiration as she had been eating her medications 
with applesauce prior to the event. A repeat CXR in the ED was 
negative for aspiration, but may have been premature to 
visualize any changes. The differential also included airway 
reactivity, given the recent admission for reactive airways. She 
was quickly weaned to room air with nebulizer treatments. Given 
the concern for mild respiratory distress a third CXR was done 
on the floor, again without any signs of infiltrate or acute 
pathology. There was evidence of mild volume overload and pt 
received 10mg IV lasix. On the previous admission the patient 
was evaluated by SLP who recommended a diet of ground solids and 
thin liquids. SLP was re consulted this admission, and the 
patient underwent a video swallow due to concerns for bedside 
aspiration, which revealed penetration and trace aspiration, and 
the patient was initiated on a diet of ground solids and nectar 
thickened liquids. She was also seen by nutrition who 
recommended supplementation with ensure plus TID. She was 
continued on atrovent and albuterol nebulizer treatmens, and 
fluticasone inhaler. Of note, albuterol was used cautiously as 
caused pt to become tachycardiac.

# Hyponatremia - RESOLVED
Patient with new mild hyponatremia to 130, with concomitant 
hypochloremia. Likely secondary to hypovolemia given improvement 
with IVF. 
 
# Coagulopathy Elevated PTT - RESOLVED
Patient with newly elevated PTT on admission. On recent 
admission patient appears to have been on heparin 5000 U TID, 
though patient is of normal BMI, likely the etioloy of the 
elevated PTT. No concomitant elevation in INR, no 
thrombocytopenia to suggest DIC. No history of elevated PTT in 
the past to suggest the presence of an acquired or intrinsic 
inhibitor. Resolved with holding subC heparin. The patient was 
restarted on subC heparin for VTE prophylaxis with BID dosing 
without elevation in PTT

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old single Caucasian man with reported history 
of depression s/p one psychiatric hospitalization in ___ ___ for depression and suicidal ideation, 
history of intermittent cannabis use, who presented to ___ via 
EMS after his roommates were concerned for several hours of 
bizarre behaviors. ED course was notable for agitation with 
patient requiring mechanical and chemical restraints. 
. 
Initial presentation was concerning for severe psychosis with 
apparent acute onset (per collateral was seen by his parents 
about a week prior to presentation and appeared to be at his 
baseline) with ED course notable for grandiosity, irritability,
disorganized and tangential thought process, as well as 
agitation requiring numerous physical and chemical restraints. 
Interview on my examination was significantly more reassuring, 
with patient notably calm, cooperative with thought process that 
is linear, goal and future oriented. Of note, he denies AVH and 
he does not appear to be responding to internal stimuli. 
. 
In terms of etiology, presentation seems most consistent with 
substance induced psychosis, although the patient denies recent 
illicit substance use and his tox screen was negative on 
admission. Differential also includes brief psychotic disorder, 
bipolar disorder (although no clear history of mania in the 
past-- remains on the differential given young age with ?family 
history of bipolar). Has reportedly been depressed in the past, 
but denies depressive symptoms on examination and does not 
appear dysthymic or dysphoric on examination.  
. 
#. Legal/Safety: patient admitted to Deaconess ___ on a ___, upon admission, he declined to sign a CV, stating he wished 
to be discharged home. Patient maintained his safety throughout 
his hospitalization on 15 minute checks and did not require 
physical or chemical restraints. Given his good behavioral 
control with resolution of psychotic symptoms with consistent

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female admitted to the hospital with  abdominal 
pain, nausea, and elevated white blood cell count.  Upon 
admission, the patient was made NPO, given intravenous fluids, 
and underwent imaging which showed perforated appendicitis. She 
was started on a course of antibiotics ceftriaxone and flagyl 
and underwent serial abdominal examinations. 

The patient was taken to the operating room on HD # 3 where she 
underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy.  Intra-operative findings 
were notable for acute perforated appendicitis with phlegmon and 
an abscess.  There was a 100 cc blood loss.  The patient was 
extubated after the procedure and monitored in the recovery 
room.  

During the post-operative course, she was febrile with an 
elevated white blood cell count. Her surgical pain was 
controlled with intravenous analgesia. Because of the 
temperature spikes, the patient underwent a cat scan of the 
abdomen on POD #5 and she was reported to have a right lower 
quadrant collection.  She was taken to interventional radiology 
where a drain was placed. Her abdominal pain persisted and she 
underwent another cat scan of the abdomen which showed an 
additional fluid collection posterior to the uterus.  She 
returned to ___ on POD #11 where another drain was placed.  Over 
the next ___ hours her white blood cell count began to normalize. 
 She continued on her course of ceftriaxone and flagyl.  

The patient was discharged home on POD #14.  Her antibiotics 
were discontinued and her white blood cell count was stable at 
11. She was transitioned to oral analgesia and was voiding 
without difficulty.  She had return of bowel function.  Her 
vital signs were stable and she was afebrile.  Discharge 
instructions were reviewed and questions answered.  A follow-up 
appointment was made in the Acute care clinic.

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Of note, during the patient's hospitalization, she noted a left 
leg lesion.  The Dermatology service was consulted and advised 
removal of the lesion.  An appointment was made for follow-up by 
the Dermatology service.   They will call the patient with the 
time and place of the appointment.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and found 
to have a perforation in your appendix. You were given IV 
antibiotics but continued to have pain and signs and symptoms of 
infection. You were taken to the operating room to have your 
appendix removed laparoscopically, and the infection washout out 
of your abdomen. After surgery, you continued to an elevation in 
your white blood cell count.  On imaging, you were reported to 
have fluid collections in your abdomen for which drains were 
placed.  Since then, your white blood cell count and your pain 
has decreased.  You continue on antibiotics.  Your are preparing 
for discharge home with ___ services for drain care assistance 
with the following instructions:

Please follow up at the appointment in clinic listed below. We 
also generally recommend that patients follow up with their 
primary care provider after having surgery. We have scheduled an 
appointment for you listed below.
ACTIVITY:
 
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs. 
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for ___ weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
You may feel weak or "washed out" a couple weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You could have a poor appetite for a couple days. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressings you have small plastic bandages 
called steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay.
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medicaitons. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not 
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed. Do not drink alcohol or 
drive while taking narcotic pain medication.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.
 
DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound

You will also need to follow-up with Dermatology to have 
excision of lesion left lower leg.
 
 
 
 
  
  
  
 
.
.
.
. 

You are now doing better, tolerating a regular diet and ready to 
be discharged home to continue your recovery.

abdominal exams and she was made NPO with IV fluid.

wall thickening of the cecum and surrounding soft tissues in the

and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and had 
abdominal/pelvic CT scans showing mild inflammation of your 
colon.  You tested positive for clostridium difficile, a 
bacteria in the colon, which can lead to bowel inflammation and 
diarrhea.  You were started on a medication, called Vancomycin, 
to treat this bacterial infection.  You are now tolerating a 
regular diet and are ready to be discharged from the hospital.

Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure to take care of you during your stay at ___. 
You came in with shortness of breath and were found to have an 
abnormal fast heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation. We were 
unable to slow down your heart rate with medicines, so we 
scheduled you for an echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart) 
which showed no clot, and then shocked the heart. This 
successfully converted your heart back to normal rhythm. 

You had a little extra fluid on your body from your heart not 
pumping efficiently while it was in Afib. We diuresed you with 
lasix and will be sending you home a small dose of lasix 20mg to 
take daily at home.

After the conversion, you had some very long pauses of your 
heart beat. Because of this we want you to wear a heart rhythm 
monitor for ___ weeks at home, to make sure you are not having 
more pauses, and also monitor if you go back into Afib. ___ 
___ will be in touch with you about this heart monitor, 
which you will receive at home in the mail within 3 business 
days.

We discussed the importance of wearing your CPAP to prevent 
converting back to Afib, and also to prevent the pauses we 
observed. Talk to your PCP about getting reconnected to a sleep 
center to keep your CPAP machine maintained and make sure you 
have the best-fitting mask.

When people are in atrial fibrillation, they are at risk of 
developing clots in the heart, which can break off and cause a 
stroke. To prevent this risk, you will need to take a blood 
thinner called warfarin, in case you go back into atrial 
fibrillation.  You will have to get your INR (a measure of how 
thin your blood is) checked regularly with the ___ 
clinic at ___ to make sure you are on the right 
dose of warfarin. You should get your INR checked tomorrow, 
___.

___ with history of CML with new fatigue who was found to have
